sentences.sContent: a struggle for power within the ruling elite
sentences.sCn: 统治阶层内部的争权夺利

sentences.sContent: ...the group helps the students get into other elite summer math programs...
...and teach children to question authority figures and navigate elite institutions...
...Contestants of elite high school math competitions are mostly Asian and white students from well-off 	families...
...The reality of it is that a lot of low-income kids could be going to elite universities on a full ride scholarship and don't even realize it...
...Jones represents a small percentage of first-generation students who are able to gain entry into more elite universities...
...many students from low-income families don't know they could have a chance of going to an elite university...
...Some elite universities attach great importance to building up the first-generation students' self-confidence...
...It's not only the selective and elite institutions that provide those opportunities for a small subset of this population...
...More American women hold elite job positions in business than Swedish women...
...Their answer: Broad-based welfare-state policies hinder women's representation in elite competitive positions...
...are reducing the number of women in elite competitive positions...
...Members of the global elite debated that unusual question at the annual World Economic Forum...
...Some critics blame affirmative action – students admitted with lower test scores and grades from shaky high schools often struggle at elite schools...

remMethod.val: e ＋ lite(=lig， 选择) → 选出来的都是精英 → 精英

words.tran: 精英主义；杰出人物统治论

trans.tranCn: [总称] 上层人士， 掌权人物， 实力集团； [总称]出类拔萃的人， 精英
trans.tranOther: a group of people who have a lot of power and influence because they have money, knowledge, or special skills
